ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.: A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of a number of technologies that permits the visualization and acquisition of images into a physical or electronic record.

Concepts.definition: Any of a number of technologies that permits the visualization and acquisition of images into a physical or electronic record.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which tissue is removed.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient._A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

Concepts.definition: Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An assessment of an individual's physical, mental, or emotional condition; information can be gathered from multiple sources, including physical exam, personal interview and observation, medical history, laboratory and imaging tests.

Concepts.definition: An assessment of an individual's physical, mental, or emotional condition; information can be gathered from multiple sources, including physical exam, personal interview and observation, medical history, laboratory and imaging tests.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The outcome of a laboratory test.

Concepts.definition: The outcome of a laboratory test.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.21 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002164. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which high-frequency sound waves are bounced off internal organs and the echo pattern is converted into a 2 dimensional picture of the structures beneath the transducer.

Concepts.definition: The use of high-frequency sound waves to generate images of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears._A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

Concepts.definition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.
A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to or using sight; able to be seen._A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or using sight; able to be seen.
A formal or careful inspection of an object or subject.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A substance sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood, other body fluids, or tissues and which may mean that a certain type of cancer is in the body. Examples of tumor markers include CA 125 (ovarian cancer), CA 15-3 (breast cancer), CEA (ovarian, lung, breast, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract cancers), and PSA (prostate cancer). Also called biomarker.

Concepts.definition: A substance present in or produced by a tumor or by the host, that can be used for differentiating neoplastic from normal tissue based on measurements in body fluids, secretions, cells, and/or tissues. Markers are used in diagnosis, staging and prognosis of cancer, provide an estimation of tumor burden, and serve for monitoring effects of therapy, detecting recurrence, localization of tumors, and screening in general populations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Aspirate from bone marrow.

Concepts.definition: Aspirate from bone marrow.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nuclear medicine finding obtained using FDG-PET imaging technique.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear medicine finding obtained using FDG-PET imaging technique.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), localizes to adrenergic tissue and is taken up and accumulates in the granules of pre-synaptic adrenergic neurons. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.: The data or image obtained by gathering information with a sensing device.

Concepts.definition: A synthetic, aralkylguanidine analogue of the adrenergic neurotransmitter norepinephrine (NE) and adrenergic neuron blocking agent with potential diagnostic imaging or antineoplastic activity when radiolabeled. Iobenguane, also known as metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), is taken up and accumulates in the granules of adrenal medullary chromaffin cells and in the pre-synaptic granules of adrenergic neurons in a manner almost identical with that of NE. In radiolabeled forms, iobenguane may be used to image or eradicate neuroendocrine tissues and tumor cells.
The data or image obtained by gathering information with a sensing device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc 4.23.19

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.:The words of something written.

Concepts.definition: A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.
The words of something written.
